macro.para:
This macro expands to an in terms of s. This , when invoked, expands to another in terms of (s). This last contains the first half of an invocation of x. This is demonstrated by the following pseudo-code:
x((s),
Note that the above pseudo-code is dramatically simplified from the actual result. It is intended to be illustrative only.

The partial invocation mentioned previously must be closed before x is actually invoked. This is accomplished with , with any other arguments to x beyond s in between:
(x)()(s, x) ... ()
For example, the expression...
(MACRO)()(s, MACRO) p, q ()
roughly results in...
MACRO((s), p, q)

The primarily utility of and is that usage allows the the arguments in between the and invocations to fully expand before x is ever invoked--even if the arguments are other uses of and . This allows direct use of the token-pasting and stringizing operators inside x. The result is effectively a trampolined invocation of x, but it is unlike because it spends a single .

Normal usage consists of invoking without the trailing invocations, passing that result around, and finishing the invocation at another time. This avoids repeatedly detecting the difference between a macro name and a .
#define MACRO(s, x) MACRO_I(s, x, (x)) #define MACRO_I(s, x, _x) _x()(s, x) ~ ()
